places.generalDescription: The Haci Bayram Mosque, constructed in the 15th century by Architect Mehmet Bey, is a significant Ottoman-era landmark located in Ulus. The mosque features brick outer walls on stone and is accompanied by the Haci Bayram-i Veli Tomb. Named after the prominent religious scholar Haci Bayram Veli, it reflects a blend of Seljuk and early Ottoman architectural styles with intricate tile work and ornate calligraphy.

sources.snippet: Hacƒ± Bayram Veli (1352-1430) was a Sufi (Muslim mystic) teacher born near Ankara. He became a follower of Sheikh Hamiduddin Veli, and after the sheik‚Äôs death in 1412, he assumed leadership of the sheik‚Äôs followers, a Sufi order that became known as the Bayrami. Because of his wisdom and erudition, Hacƒ± Bayram was an advisor to Sultan Murat II (1404-1451), father of Sultan Mehmet II ‚ÄúThe Conqueror.
sources.shortName: What to See & Do in Ankara, Turkey

sources.snippet: The Haci Bayram Mosque is one of the most historically significant mosques in Ankara and Turkey. An iconic religious centre based on the 17th century and 18th-century mosque architectural styles, it is home to the mausoleum of Turkish poet and Sufi Haci Bayram Veli, whose name it takes. The site also includes a Roman Temple of Augustus where the walls depict how it looked during the Roman times.
sources.shortName: 40 Best Things to do in Ankara Turkey 2025

sources.snippet: This beautiful mosque, located in the Ulus district, is one of the oldest and most significant religious sites in Ankara. Admire its Ottoman architecture and peaceful ambiance.The Haci Bayram Mosque is a significant religious and cultural site located in Ankara, Turkey. Here's what you can expect when visiting the Haci Bayram Mosque:
sources.shortName: Top Things To Do In Ankara

sources.snippet: Constructed back in the fifteenth century, the Haci Bayram Mosque is a token of dedication to Haji Bayram Wali, the preacher and founder of the Baryam Sufi order.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Ankara, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

places.name: Haci Bayram Mosque

reviews.text:
Hacƒ± Bayram Veli Mosque is one of the most beautiful and peaceful places to visit in Ankara, MashaAllah.
We visited here after exploring Ankara Castle and offered Asar Namaz in this serene environment.
The mosque holds great historical significance as one of the oldest mosques in the city, dating back to the Ottoman Empire period. Named after the Turkish Sufi and poet Hacƒ± Bayram-ƒ± Veli, it offers a fascinating blend of spiritual and historical value.

The surrounding area is equally captivating. Behind the mosque, you'll find a park with ancient signs of the past, including monuments from the Roman era, over 2100 years old. The traditional handcraft shops nearby add to the cultural richness of the experience.

In addition to its beauty and history, Hacƒ± Bayram Mosque offers excellent views of Ankara city. The ‚ôøaccessibility is well thought out, with a dedicated üÖøÔ∏èparking lot and a lift making it easy for everyone to reach the mosque.
A must-visit if you're in Ankara!

I loved my visit to the mosque. A lot if history present. New mosque is very beautiful inside. Visited the grave of Haci Bayram and offered fatiha.
There are some nice restaurants and shops around to spend time in your own or with family

The mosque was built in the early 15th century in honor of Hacƒ± Bayram Veli, a prominent Turkish Sufi and founder of the Bayrami Sufi Order. The mosque was constructed shortly after his death and became a center for spiritual learning and devotion. Over the centuries, the mosque has undergone several renovations, blending Seljuk and Ottoman architectural styles, which gives it a unique charm.

Architecture and Features

The Hacƒ± Bayram Mosque has a simple yet elegant design. Its brick and stone structure, along with its wooden roof, reflects the architectural style of its era. Inside, the mosque is adorned with beautiful calligraphy and wooden decorations. Despite its modest size, it exudes a deep sense of serenity, enhanced by the spiritual significance of the place.

Spiritual and Cultural Importance

As a spiritual hub, the mosque continues to attract both worshippers and visitors from around the country and beyond. It is particularly busy during religious holidays and special events, and many people visit the tomb of Hacƒ± Bayram Veli, located adjacent to the mosque, to pay their respects.

The proximity to the Temple of Augustus also highlights Ankara's cultural layers, with ancient Roman history sitting alongside Ottoman and Islamic heritage.

Visitor Experience

Visiting the Hacƒ± Bayram Mosque offers a peaceful and reflective experience. The surrounding area has been recently developed into a lively plaza with shops and cafes, making it an enjoyable stop for both spiritual and cultural exploration.

Overall, the Hacƒ± Bayram Mosque is a must-visit for anyone interested in Ankara's historical and religious landscape.

places.address: Hacƒ± Bayram, Sarƒ±baƒü Sk. No:13, 06050 Altƒ±ndaƒü/Ankara, T√ºrkiye

places.generalDescription: Anƒ±tkabir in Ankara is a grand mausoleum and museum dedicated to Kemal Ataturk, the founding father and first president of the Republic of Turkey. It also serves as the final resting place for Ismet Inonu, Turkey's second president. The site features a marble hall, turrets, murals, and art galleries. The Ataturk Museum within Anƒ±tkabir displays his personal items, medals, wardrobe, and gifts received during his lifetime.

sources.snippet: Located in the √áankaya neighbourhood of Ankara, close to the Occidental Ankara, Anƒ±tkabir is a mausoleum complex and the eternal resting place of Mustafa Kemal Atat√ºrk, the founding father and first president of the Turkish Republic. Many Turks call him father and adore him meanwhile others despise him and remember him as a secular extremist. Yet, politics aside, his work to Europeanise Turkey along with his efforts for gender equality make him one of the country‚Äôs most famous public figures.
sources.shortName: Our pick of the best

sources.snippet: Anƒ±tkabir is a magnificent mausoleum dedicated to the founder and [...]. sources.snippet: One of the most notable modern architecture examples sitting high on Ankara‚Äôs hilltop has to be the Atat√ºrk Mausoleum, Anƒ±tkabir. It was designed by Emil Onat, the renowned Turkish architect who constructed its complex between the years 1944 to 1953. This mausoleum is known to be the sepulture place of the Turkish Republic‚Äôs first president and founder Mustafa Kemal Atat√ºrk.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Ankara, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: The father of the modern Turkish Republic, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, found his resting place at the Anitkabir, a mausoleum in Ankara. Standing tall on a hilltop, this mausoleum is elaborate and carved with intricate designs. The complex has many areas to explore, like the Hall of Honor, Peacock Park, Aslanlƒ± Yol‚Äô, and Monument Block, among others.
sources.shortName: 40 Best Things to do in Ankara Turkey 2025

sources.snippet: Anƒ±tkabir is the mausoleum of Mustafa Kemal Atat√ºrk, the founder of the Republic of Turkey, also known as the ‚ÄúFather of the Turks‚Äù. Built on a vast area in the middle of central Ankara in 1952, Anƒ±tkabir receives thousands of visitors every day. It is open every day between 9am ‚Äì 4pm.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Visit in Ankara, Turkey

sources.snippet: The Anƒ±tkabir (Monumental Tomb) of the founder of the Turkish Republic, Kemal Atat√ºrk (1881-1938), crowns a hilltop in the Maltepe district. The great monument itself and a small museum of Atat√ºrk‚Äôs life are open to the public. This is the most precious and respected place for Turks.

sources.snippet: If you have very little time in Ankara, this should be your first stop. The most historic monument for the Turkish Republic, the Anitkabir, sits on an enormous hilltop and holds the mausoleum of

places.name: Anƒ±tkabir

reviews.text: It's an impressive area and easy to navigate. Attaturk is beloved by all Turkish people for his remarkable achievements. It's definitely worth a visit if you are in Ankara. It's also free, which was a nice surprise.

Amazing place especially the informative museum. Security is tight and can take a while to clear. Our guide told us dslr cameras üì∑ are not allowed in. However,  on entry we noticed a number of people with them. At exit, asked the Security about this, and he advised that as long the camera and lens don't appear large,  it's permitted. Not advisable to take more than one lens, so take a zoom type.
Also be prepared for large crowds  especially at weekends.
Changing of guard is worth watching üëÄ. It happens every hour at quarter past hour.

I love the experience most especially the changing of the guards. It is a much awaited and MUST see! The museum is very well kept. The arts are really amazing! I just wish that people really adhere to not smoking in the area. Overall, it was a great experience.

places.generalDescription: Kuƒüulu Park, also known as Swan Park, is a popular urban oasis located in the heart of Ankara's bustling Tunali Hilmi shopping street. The park features picturesque walking paths, a children's playground, and a serene pond inhabited by swans, geese, and ducks. Visitors can relax on park benches and immerse themselves in the city's daily life before exploring nearby shops and cafes. At night, the park transforms with illuminated fountains and bridges creating a captivating ambiance.

sources.snippet: Tunalƒ± Street‚Äôs famous Kuƒüulu Park (Swan Park) has, true to its name, a small man-made lake with pretty swans gliding around beautifully.
sources.shortName: All You Need To Know About Ankara In 20 Instagram Photos

sources.snippet: Ever since it‚Äôs opening in 1995 on Tunalƒ± Hilmi Caddesi in Ankara‚Äôs √áankaya district, Cafe des Cafes has been synonymous with the sweet nostalgia of the capital, which holds high importance for so many. Meanwhile, Kuƒüulu Park, which in English literally means ‚ÄúSwan Park‚Äù and is not to be confused with the nearby A≈üƒ±klar Parkƒ±, is located in the heart of the consular neighborhood of the capital. There are grassy knolls and play areas for children, but the true highlight for many are the ponds and the parks' resident ducks and swans, which you can conveniently watch from comfortable benches lining the park.
sources.shortName: Most romantic destinations in Ankara for Valentine's Day

places.name: Kuƒüulu Park

reviews.text: Really nice park in the center of bustling city where you can relax while enjoying Nature. Many birds including swans, pigeons, ducks etc makes relaxing even more enjoyable. Water fountains give a pleasing sound that sooth your eyes as well as ears.  Highly recommended.

We visited this park as we were in the area around. It was filled with people. I loved the bridges and waterfall inside it. When I looked at the people's faces, they seemed to like their experience. By the way, the area of this park is not very big. It was a nice visit.

Nice little park in the center of the city. Not big, mostly crowded but still great place to visit. Many birds, swans, ducks. Playing area for children, many coffee shops around for parents. Clean and peaceful place. Recommend to visit for everyone

places.generalDescription: The Ataturk Statue, built in 1927 as a memorial for the Turkish War of Independence, features bronze figures including the prominent leader riding on horseback. The monument serves as a symbol of Turkey's struggle for independence and honors those who fought for their nation's freedom. The statue is an impressive piece of art that stands tall and proud, representing the strength and resilience of the Turkish people during difficult times.

sources.snippet: The Ataturk Statue, located in Ulus Square of Ankara near Atat√ºrk Boulevard, is a group of bronze statues depicting soldiers in a battlefield. Built during the Turkish War of Independence, the central figure of the monument is that of an equestrian figure of Mustafa Kemal Atat√ºrk, the founder of the Republic of Turkey and a military officer during World War I. There are three more figures of two s (Read More)oldiers and one woman.
sources.shortName: 40 Best Things to do in Ankara Turkey 2025

places.name: Ataturk Statue

reviews.text:
The Atat√ºrk Statue in Ulus, Ankara, is one of the most iconic monuments dedicated to Mustafa Kemal Atat√ºrk, the founder of the Republic of Turkey. Located in the heart of the city's historic Ulus district, it serves as a symbol of Turkish independence and the reforms led by Atat√ºrk.

The statue depicts Atat√ºrk in military attire, often on horseback, symbolizing his leadership during the Turkish War of Independence. It was designed by the Austrian sculptor Heinrich Krippel and was inaugurated on August 24, 1927. This monument is significant as it reflects the deep respect and admiration the Turkish people have for Atat√ºrk and his role in shaping modern Turkey.

The surrounding Ulus Square is also historically important as it was the administrative center of the Turkish Republic in its early years. The statue is often a focal point for national celebrations and ceremonies, particularly on public holidays like Republic Day (October 29) and Victory Day (August 30).

The Ulus Atat√ºrk Monument was designed by Austrian sculptor Heinrich Krippel as a result of an international competition announced in 1925. Construction of the monument began in 1927, and the unveiling took place on November 24 of the same year. The base of the statue is made of Italian marble, and the figures are made of bronze
Nice place for photos and rendezvous or merry up after dispersal from a group. Near a local market that sells varieties of food, bread, vegetables, meat, and fish.

places.address: Hacƒ± Bayram, Anafartalar Cd No:62, 06050 Altƒ±ndaƒü/Ankara, T√ºrkiye

places.generalDescription: Ankara Castle, an ancient fortress perched on a rocky hill, provides breathtaking panoramic views of the city. With its strong fortifications and intricate architecture, this historic site offers visitors a glimpse into Turkey's past. The castle has been used by various civilizations for defense and settlement over its 4,000-year history and has undergone numerous repairs. Inside the castle, there are houses dating back to different historical periods, providing insight into the area's evolution.

sources.snippet: On a cloudy day, the view from the Ankara Castle is truly beautiful, with the city unfurling right before your eyes under the gray sky.
sources.shortName: All You Need To Know About Ankara In 20 Instagram Photos

sources.snippet: Ankara Castle is one of Ankara's most prominent tourist destinations, a very old one, known for its strong fortifications, delicate architecture, and strategic location on top of a hill, enabling visitors to see Turkey's capital from all sides. Ankara Castle has many small squares used for various commercial purposes and gathering points, most notably horse market squares and sheep market. The castle's interior has houses of only two or three floors, dating back to different historical stages, and visitors can see the contemporary neighbourhood scene in stunning paintings.
sources.shortName: Top 7 Tourist Places in Ankara

sources.snippet: Head to the highest corner of Ankara and get ready to explore the Castle. Inside the main gate of the old city, you will find quaint coffee shops serving piping hot traditional Turkish coffee next to artisan shops selling rugs and Turkish evil eyes and old-fashioned houses converted into chic restaurants. As you reach the viewpoint, you will be able to admire the ever-unfolding views of the city, best seen at sunset when the last call to prayer echoes through the sun-tinged air.
sources.shortName: Our pick of the best

sources.snippet: Referred to in Turkish as Ankara Kalesi and in English as the "Citadel," this commandeering castle and its walled fortifications, set above a rocky hill with a 360-degree commandeering view of the capital, is a wonderful site to visit. First founded in the eighth century B.C. by the Phrygians and rebuilt multiple times by many civilizations, including the Roman, Byzantine, Sel√ßuk and Ottoman eras.
sources.shortName: Most romantic destinations in Ankara for Valentine's Day

sources.snippet: One of Turkey's oldest sites, the Ankara Castle is a historical fortification dating back to the 7th century. The castle overlooks the city from its peak and is often associated with Ottoman, Seljuk, Roman and Byzantine empires. One of Ankara's must-visit destinations, the castle embodies different architectural styles and is home to twenty pillars and two gateways.
sources.shortName: 40 Best Things to do in Ankara Turkey 2025

sources.snippet: The views of the sprawling city from the top of the castle spread out before you and invite you to snap a few pictures. The build date isn‚Äôt know but historian say it postdates the capture and destruction of Ankara by the Persians in probably 622. Just like the city, the castle has fallen through many hands such as the Roman, Byzantine, Seljuk, and Ottoman empires.
sources.shortName: TURKEY: Top 5 sites in Ankara, Turkey

sources.snippet: Built by the Phrygians and renovated by Romans, Byzantines, and Ottomans, it offers panoramic views of Ankara. Wander through historic streets filled with Ottoman-era houses, quaint shops, and art galleries, immersing yourself in centuries of culture and craftsmanship.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Ankara, Tourist Places & Top Attractions
Things to do and Photograph in Ankara Turkey

places.name: Ankara Castle

reviews.text: We have been here twice already and we are never tired of it! You can have a cup of coffee or tea in a small cafe inside the yard. You can enjoy the great view from above. You can buy souvenirs from local people and have a taste of traditional items. Take your time to go up and admire the view!

Ankara Castle is a historical landmark with amazing panoramic views of the city. Walking through its old walls and narrow streets feels like traveling back in time. Around the castle, you can find beautiful shops with souvenirs, accessories, and charming caf√©s designed in an old traditional style. It's a must-visit spot in Ankara for history lovers and anyone who enjoys exploring authentic places

Ankara Castle is a must-visit! The panoramic views of the city from the top are absolutely breathtaking. Walking through the ancient stone walls and narrow pathways felt like stepping back in time. The atmosphere is rich with history, and there are charming shops and caf√©s nearby to explore. It's a fantastic spot for history enthusiasts and photographers alike!

places.generalDescription: Kocatepe Mosque, a stunning example of neoclassical Ottoman architecture, stands as the largest mosque in Ankara and one of Turkey's most impressive religious structures. Completed between 1967 and 1987, it boasts an expansive area of 4,500 square meters that can accommodate over 24,000 worshippers. Perched on Kocatepe Hill, this architectural marvel features four soaring minarets and a grand central dome that captures the eye from afar.

sources.snippet: This mosque, whose construction was completed in 1987, has the distinction of being the largest mosque in Ankara. You should definitely visit this mosque, which will fascinate you with its architecture.
sources.shortName: What to See & Do in Ankara, Turkey

sources.snippet: In comparison to other mosques in the city, Kocatepe is relatively newer. Located at a short walking distance from Kƒ±zƒ±lay, Kocatepe is a must-visit spot in Ankara.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Visit in Ankara, Turkey
8 Things to do in Ankara, Turkey
Things to do and Photograph in Ankara Turkey

places.name: Kocatepe Mosque

reviews.text: The Kocatepe Mosque (Turkish: Kocatepe Camii) is an awe-inspiring masterpiece and the largest mosque in Ankara, Turkey. Constructed between 1967 and 1987 in the vibrant Kocatepe quarter of Kƒ±zƒ±lay, its grandeur and commanding presence have made it a prominent landmark, visible from nearly every corner of central Ankara. The mosque's architecture is breathtaking, blending classical Ottoman design with modern influences, creating a majestic and peaceful atmosphere. The mosque's design is meticulously planned, with the women's prayer area located on the first floor, while the spacious ground floor is reserved for men. Whether you're admiring its towering minarets or stepping inside to experience its serene beauty, Kocatepe Mosque is a true symbol of Ankara's cultural and architectural pride

After reading a lot on the internet that this visit is a must, we stopped by this place in our visit to Ankara. I loved the architecture  of this place. The interior design is very beautiful. It was a nice visit. If you were nearby, it is nice to see this place.

Mosque is a magnificent structure and a must-visit in Ankara. The architecture is stunning, and the sheer size of the mosque is awe-inspiring. What truly made our visit memorable was the kindness of the imam, who took the time to share valuable insights about Islam and the mosque itself. He even allowed us to go up to the top of the minarets, offering an incredible view of the city. The atmosphere is peaceful, and the interior is beautifully designed. A wonderful experience that deepened my appreciation for this cultural and spiritual landmark!

places.generalDescription: G√ºvenpark, located in the Kizilay district of Ankara, Turkey, is a well-established urban oasis that has been around since the 1930s. The park is renowned for its iconic G√ºven Monument and offers a serene atmosphere with lush greenery and well-maintained surroundings. It's designed to provide a peaceful escape from the city's hustle and bustle, making it an ideal retreat for locals and visitors alike.

sources.snippet: G√ºvenpark is a historic urban park located in the heart of Ankara's Kƒ±zƒ±lay district. Established in the 1930s as part of the city's early republican development, it serves as a central recreational area and a significant cultural landmark. G√ºven Monument is the central feature of the park and a tribute to Turkey's security forces.
sources.shortName: 40 Best Things to do in Ankara Turkey 2025

places.name: G√ºvenpark

reviews.text:
the place is always crowded with people hanging out around.
the bus stops are always full of people waiting for their bus. the park is nice with a lot of seats available. but be careful of birds above you, they can drop some dirts.
some rest rooms are underground near some marketplaces inside.

G√ºvenpark is a lovely spot to take a break from the city's hustle and bustle. The tall trees provide plenty of shade, making it a perfect place for a relaxing walk or just sitting on a bench and enjoying the fresh air. The statues and monuments add a historical touch, and the central location makes it super easy to visit.

It can get a bit crowded, especially on weekends, but that just adds to its charm. Whether you're passing by or looking for a quiet moment, it's worth stopping here. Definitely a refreshing spot in the middle of Kƒ±zƒ±lay!

The park is a detachment from the most crowded part of the city to chill for some minutes and decide your next step. There's always something going on Police are around, army, Red cross blood donations, International organization and much more camp here. But it's not very well designed. It's so small for the population and water fountains are usually out of service.

places.generalDescription: Atakule, situated in the Cankaya district of Ankara, is a must-visit destination offering a unique blend of retail therapy, dining experiences, and breathtaking views. Standing tall at 125 meters, this iconic tower provides unparalleled panoramic vistas of Ankara. The revolving restaurant within Atakule offers an exceptional dining experience with ever-changing urban landscapes as it rotates. From this vantage point, visitors can marvel at the city's rich history and diverse civilizations that once thrived here.

sources.snippet: One of the capital‚Äôs landmarks is Atakule, which protrudes into the sky like a spaceship entity, especially at night when illuminated with different colored lights.
sources.shortName: All You Need To Know About Ankara In 20 Instagram Photos

sources.snippet: Located in the Canakaya district, the Atakule Tower overlooks Ankara from a height of 125 meters above the sea level. The panoramic view of the city alongside good food is definitely a plus, with a revolving restaurant and a caf√©, Atakule is a great place to enjoy a romantic dinner at. The bottom structure of this tower is home to a shopping complex.
sources.shortName: 40 Best Things to do in Ankara Turkey 2025

sources.snippet: Located in the trendy and modern shopping district of Cankaya, Atakule Tower offers visitors the highest viewpoint in the city. Without question, the panoramic views from Atakule are the best in the city, as the photo above illustrates.
sources.shortName: 8 Things to do in Ankara, Turkey

sources.snippet: Atakule, one of the oldest malls in Ankara, is perhaps the most notable landmark of the city. With its glorious 125-meter-long (410 feet) observation tower, it abuts and oversees the colorful Botanical Park of Ankara.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Visit in Ankara, Turkey

sources.snippet: Discover Ankara's skyline from Atakule, a striking 125-metre tower in √áankaya. Opened in 1989, it is one of the tallest towers in the city. Atakule also offers breathtaking city views from its revolving restaurant.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Ankara, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: Atakule is one of the most identifiable landmarks of Ankara. It opened in 1989 and the viewing terrace offers panoramic views over Ankara. I recommend visiting late afternoon to witness the Ankara sunset.
sources.shortName: Things to do and Photograph in Ankara Turkey

places.name: Atakule

reviews.text:
Atakule is one of the most iconic landmarks in Ankara, offering a unique blend of modern architecture, breathtaking views, and a relaxing atmosphere. Standing tall in the √áankaya district, this observation and communications tower is not just a tourist attraction-it's a symbol of the city itself.

The tower features a panoramic terrace with 360-degree views of Ankara, making it a perfect spot for photography lovers and anyone who wants to see the capital from above. Whether you visit during the day or at night, the view is truly stunning.

Inside Atakule, you'll find a variety of restaurants, caf√©s, and shops. The revolving restaurant is a special highlight-it slowly rotates while you dine, allowing you to enjoy a changing view of the city as you eat. There's also a modern shopping area at the base of the tower, with local and international brands, making it a great place to spend a few hours.

The area around Atakule is peaceful and well-maintained, perfect for a walk or a coffee break. It's also easy to access by taxi or public transportation.

Overall, Atakule is more than just a tower-it's an experience. Whether you're a local or a visitor, I highly recommend adding it to your Ankara itinerary.üå∫üå∫üå∫‚ô•Ô∏è‚ô•Ô∏è‚ô•Ô∏èü§©

The arcade is luxurious and up-to-date, the prices of the various restaurants are higher than the Ankara city standard, but the food court is well priced and has a nice view of Ankara city. The cinema and massage chairs were also good.

Amazing view!
The ticket prices were 100 TL for students and 200 TL for adults to access the terrace (not the very top).
If you want to go all the way up to the highest level of Atakule, it costs 300 TL for students and 600 TL for adults.
I highly recommend visiting this place. there's a shopping center and a beautiful, peaceful park nearby.

places.generalDescription: Botanical Park in Ankara is a serene and tranquil green space that offers respite from the hectic pace of city life. This hidden gem boasts well-established pathways bordered by mature foliage, a vast pond, seating areas, and a play area for children. It is an idyllic retreat for nature enthusiasts and serves as a stunning backdrop for photography enthusiasts.

sources.snippet: Last, but certainly not least, is the destination in the capital known for being the most romantic spot possible. Set in √áankaya and established in the 1970s, the Botanical Park is over 65,000 square meters (around 699,600 square feet) of nature that serves as a wonderful escape from the bustle of the big city. Walk along its green paths, picnic on the grassy knolls and enjoy the greenery, mature trees, flower gardens and fountains, which now serve as the top backdrop for many of the capital‚Äôs newlywed shots.
sources.shortName: Most romantic destinations in Ankara for Valentine's Day

places.name: Botanical Park

reviews.text:
This park is an amazing escape from our busy life.
They have the cutest benches and tables for you to have a quiet picnic or hangout with your friends and family. There's also a lake in the middle.

We came here around noon and the weather was beautiful. We enjoyed our food and the scenery.  It was very relaxing.

You also get to see the Atakule tower from the garden.

Hidden Gem in the Heart of Ankara

Tucked inside one of the most beautiful parks in Ankara, this caf√© is something special. Right in the middle of the park, surrounded by greenery and a peaceful water fountain, you'll find a coffee spot that's more than just a place to grab a drink.

The caf√© is built inside what used to be a greenhouse and it still holds onto that charm. You can wander through the plants, soak in the natural light, and even buy a few if something catches your eye. The whole place has this calm, airy atmosphere that makes it perfect for studying, reading, or just escaping the noise of the city.

The coffee? 9/10. The staff? Friendly and professional. And if you're feeling bold (or just bored), there's a piano you're welcome to play.

It's aesthetically beautiful, full of unique little corners perfect for photos, and easily one of the best places in town to relax or get some work done. Highly recommend

Came here during winter and it was quiet as there weren't so many people around. You can access the park through the street uphill or from a path downhill. There is a pond and it appears to be dried out during the winter. There is also a structure that looks like a greenhouse but I didn't have the chance to go inside. There is an area that appeared to be an aquarium but apparently, it wasn't open when I got there. There is also an area for kids to play but it is located way uphill not in the downhill area.

places.generalDescription: The Turkish Air Force Museum, located in Ankara, is a captivating destination for aviation enthusiasts and families alike. This unique indoor and outdoor museum showcases an impressive collection of military aircraft, model planes, uniforms, and memorabilia that narrate the rich history of Turkish aviation. With over 700 artifacts including photographs, medals, certificates, and original aircraft from various eras‚Äîparticularly World War II‚Äîyou'll find yourself immersed in the fascinating world of flight.

sources.snippet: Built with the aim of showcasing the Turkish aviation's rich and glorious history to the world, the Ankara Air Force Museum is home to more than 700 photographs, artefacts, and documents related to the Turkish Air Agency and Turkish Civil Aviation Authority. Important exhibits displayed in the halls of this popular museum include medals, certificates, and uniforms of the Turkish Air Force.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Ankara, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: If you are interested in military airplanes, visiting this museum should be on your list of things to do in Ankara. Note that there are two museums in the city dedicated to the air force. This one is in the city, located in Altindag district, while another, Ankara Aviation Museum, is in the Etimesgut district.
sources.shortName: 19 Things to do in Ankara

places.name: Turkish Air Force Museum

reviews.text: The Air Force museum is absolutely fascinating! The collection of old aircraft is impressive, each one with its own rich history and story. Walking through the exhibits feels like stepping back in time.
A beautiful music that talks about the history of the Turkish Air Force...  Very special
Nice museum, English speaking staff, nice shop

places.generalDescription: The Altƒ±nk√∂y A√ßƒ±k Hava M√ºzesi is a great place to visit if you're looking for an outdoor museum with traditional Anatolian houses, craft and agriculture exhibits, and farm animals. The landscape is very calm and moody, so it's best to visit during spring when everything is lush green and fresh. The ticket price is 5 Turkish Lira for adults, so it's a great value for the area.

sources.snippet: The Altinkoy Open Air Museum is based on village architecture, traditions and culture of the 1930-1950s. A beautiful picnic spot, the innovative museum, located in Altƒ±ndaƒü district of Ankara, has a breathtaking green landscape covering 500 acres. Apart from being a delight for nature lovers, there are also many small museums inside, including a laundry place, a weaving workshop, a toy museum and (Read More)workshop, and a wildlife introduction museum.
sources.shortName: 40 Best Things to do in Ankara Turkey 2025

sources.snippet: If you‚Äôd like to see what life used to be in the villages in Turkey, visit this open-air museum. The complex includes examples of houses, mosques, fountains, and everything else that perfectly describe rural life some hundred years ago. There‚Äôs a farmer‚Äôs market to buy some groceries and a restaurant if you get hungry.
sources.shortName: 19 Things to do in Ankara

places.name: Altƒ±nk√∂y Open Air Museum - Altƒ±ndaƒü

reviews.text: Peaceful, calm and a very beautiful place. You will feel as you are very far from the city side, in a small forest like environment enjoying fresh air and spectacular scenarios.

I have never known such a concept village to be in Ankara. While you are walking, cows are passing and seeing them and more. That's outstanding experience you could have in city. I strongly recommend you to go with guest who come from out of ankara. You can get local flavors with good services.

This is a wonderful place to see great nature, to enjoy a peaceful moment, to see animals (chicken, geese, sheep, goats, deer etc), and buildings - all of  which resemble a village of the past. It is a popular place for models and brides to be photographed. There r restaurants at regular intervals so u can refresh yourself.  This is a place to come to for the whole afternoon. I love the water- and windmill, the kid's parks, and a long swinging bridge. (Unfortunately, it was closed due to repair when we were there.) The only issue is the menus. Every restaurant sells literally the same unhealthy food. Most are sweets and processed snacks and g√∂zleme, which is OK, but there's little filling and lots of dough. No side dish, salad or fruit available. The selection of drinks is also incredibly weak. No plant-based mylk or vegean snacks.
